pages.text: Gerobatrachus was an amphibamiform temnospondyl amphibian that lived during the lower Permian. First scientifically described in 2008, its fossils were collected in 1995 from Baylor County, Texas, specifically from a locality with the rather amusing title of Don's Dump Fish Quarry. The genus name means elder frog in Greek, while the species name hottoni honours Nicholas Hotton III, a paleontologist who worked for the National Museum of Natural History.

Sometimes referred to as a frogmander by the press, Gerobatrachus had physical features reminiscent of both frogs and salamanders, and initially it was thought to be the closest known relative of Batrachia. However, this has since been called into question, though some studies do still find it to be quite close to that clade. The well preserved fossil of this animal also shows some other general similarities to modern amphibians.
